discussion.content:
C
keep alive send every 4 sec, and try 5 times before declare the tunnel peer down

C correct, if tunnel down deppends from the actual time of tunnel disconnection in regard with the hold timer value at that moment (it will reset every 4 sec, but will wait for 5 sec), so it can take up to almost 9 sec to detect, so C is correct

comments.content: (it will reset every 4 sec, but will try for 5 times), so it will last 20 seconds to bring the interface to the down state

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit. How does the GRE keepalive configuration affect tunnel operation on these two routers?
//IMG//

choices.B: R1 will detect tunnel failures within 5 seconds
choices.A: R1 will not send keepalives until keepalives are configured on R2
choices.C: R1 will detect tunnel failures within 20 seconds
choices.D: R1 will send keepalives, but R2 will not return them C

choices.C: Set the MTU to 1500 on the tunnel interfaces
choices.B: Increase the MTU on the IPv6 network
choices.A: Set the MTU to 1476 on the tunnel interfaces
choices.D: Increase the MTU on the IPv4 networks A

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit. MTU has been configured as shown, and no MTU command has been configured on the tunnel interfaces. It has been found that fragmentation is occurring when tunneled packets are placed onto the IPv6 underlay network. Which configuration change will resolve this problem?
//IMG//

discussion.content: A is correct, IPV6 has a bigger header and its all included in the 1500 packet, so ipv4 packets at the tunnel endpoints when encapsulated need also to include ipv4 header at least 8 byte, also gre, so mtu size must be set lower to avoit fragmentation

choices.C: Check HQ-Firewall to see if it's blocking HTTP traffic
choices.D: Run a traceroute to www.cisco.com D
choices.A: Check the physical link from HQ-Firewall to HQ-Sw1

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit. BR-PC1 (192.168.100.10) is unable to reach the Internet. Access to the Internet is routed through the HQ site and all NAT configurations have been applied and verified. The user on BR-PC1 has attempted to ping www.cisco.com and did not receive any responses. Which troubleshooting step will assist with root cause analysis by displaying a series of upstream connected devices?
//IMG//

discussion.content: Displaying upstream connected devices, D is the correct answer

D is the correct answer.

Tunnel recursive route appear when tunnel destination routed through the tunnel itself.

choices.B: The local tunnel mode does not match the tunnel mode configured on the remote router.
choices.C: The shutdown command has been issued on the source physical interface.
choices.D: The installed route to the tunnel destination has been learned via the tunnel interface. D
choices.A: The remote router's tunnel interface is not participating in the routing process.

questions.question_text: A syslog message from a router with a GRE tunnel reads: "%TUN-5-RECURDOWN: Tunnel0 temporarily disabled due to recursive routing". Which scenario would cause this error?

discussion.content:
C 
When transport input ssh missing, admin can't ssh to the device

choices.D: The old RSA key pair needs to be deleted first C
choices.A: Only SSHv1 is allowed and you are trying to configure SSHv2
choices.C: The transport input ssh command is missing

questions.question_text: An engineer is attempting to configure a secure connection to a device. During testing, the login is not working. Which statement describes the root cause?
